unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi reports a surge in cases of acute gastroenteritis, especially among children under 5 yrs old, during the monsoon season. Dr. R. K. Sharma, Head of Gastroenterology, advises boiling water for 10 mins before consumption to kill potential pathogens. Symptoms reported include severe abdominal pain, vomiting 3-4 times a day, and dehydration.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reports a surge in cases of acute gastroenteritis, especially among children under five years old, during the monsoon season. Doctor R. K. Sharma, Head of Gastroenterology, advises boiling water for ten minutes before consumption to kill potential pathogens. Symptoms reported include severe abdominal pain, vomiting three to four times a day, and dehydration.

unnormalised: The hospital saw approx. 150 new patients with gastroenteritis in the last week of July '24, a significant increase from the usual 50 cases per week during other times of the year. This spike is attributed to contaminated water sources and unhygienic food practices prevalent during the monsoon. Patients are being treated with oral rehydration solutions (ORS) and, in severe cases, intravenous fluids.
normalised: The hospital saw approximately one hundred and fifty new patients with gastroenteritis in the last week of July twenty twenty four, a significant increase from the usual fifty cases per week during other times of the year. This spike is attributed to contaminated water sources and unhygienic food practices prevalent during the monsoon. Patients are being treated with oral rehydration solutions (O-R-S) and, in severe cases, intravenous fluids.

unnormalised: The primary cause is identified as Rotavirus, affecting mostly infants aged 6-24 months, and E. coli bacteria present in street food. Prevention measures emphasized by the health authorities include washing hands thoroughly with soap and water before meals, avoiding street food, and ensuring proper sanitation in residential areas. Families are also advised to get their children vaccinated against Rotavirus as per the recommended schedule.
normalised: The primary cause is identified as Rotavirus, affecting mostly infants aged six to twenty four months, and E. coli bacteria present in street food. Prevention measures emphasized by the health authorities include washing hands thoroughly with soap and water before meals, avoiding street food, and ensuring proper sanitation in residential areas. Families are also advised to get their children vaccinated against Rotavirus as per the recommended schedule.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the National Institute of Cholera and Enteric Diseases (NICED), Kolkata, is collaborating with AIIMS to study the genetic variations of the viruses causing the outbreak. The research aims to develop more effective diagnostic tools and treatment strategies for gastroenteritis. Initial findings suggest a new strain of norovirus may also be contributing to the rise in cases.

unnormalised: Citizens are urged to remain vigilant and follow the guidelines issued by the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare. Immediate medical attention is recommended for individuals experiencing severe symptoms. A helpline number, 1075, has been activated for reporting cases and seeking assistance.
